awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: EFRI-REM Mentoring Catalyst Initiative
awd_abstract_narration:
STEM mentoring research shows that positive mentoring experiences have a significant impact on STEM retention and broadening participation of (e.g., underrepresented Minorities (URM), women and persons with disabilities) in STEM fields.  Engineering is currently at a crossroad and everything that can be done to retain talented engineering students needs to be done.  There are few studies that focus solely on engineering mentoring and none of these studies include a significant training component for the mentors. This project plans to use and measure the impact of mentor training on engineering researchers. The EFRI Research Experience and Mentoring (EFRI-REM) program will be used as a pilot program to measure the success of inclusion of mentor training and the building of an engineering focused mentoring community on outcomes of EFRI-REM students.   

While the EFRI-REM research participants will be used to pilot this program, the outcomes will have potentially far reaching impact throughout the engineering research community.  For example, the proposed ?train the trainer? mentor training model will be broadly disseminated beyond the EFRI-REM community.   Faculty trained to facilitate mentor training will be encouraged and supported to offer training to engineering faculty and students beyond the EFRI-REM program, with potential impacts reaching the entire engineering research spectrum.  In addition, the developed online mentoring community will provide continued support for engineering mentors to discuss best practices and ongoing mentoring issues.  The impact of well-mentored students could have large potential positive impacts on retention of graduate students in engineering and encourage undergraduate engineering students to pursue advanced degrees in engineering.
org_div_long_name: Office of Emerging Frontiers in Research and Innovation (EFRI)

por.por_cntn:
This project established the EFRI-REM Mentoring Catalyst initiative, which is designed to build a mentoring community comprised of current and future science and engineering mentors. The overarching mission of this initiative is to positively impact mentors and student/teacher participants through training in mentoring. The intellectual merit of this project is that positive mentoring experiences in STEM has significant impact on the success of students in STEM fields. The broader impacts of this initiative are that we established a community of practice that facilitates institutional engagement in defining best practices in mentoring in STEM. By developing this community of practice, we have created a community that will allow for better mentoring of participants in EFRI-REM programs. 

As described above, the major outcome of this project is the development of a community of practice that facilitates sharing of best practices in mentoring STEM research participants. This was achieved by providing support for EFRI-REM faculty, graduate students and postdoctoral mentors during a variety of in-person and online conferences, symposiums and trainings. This included workshops at the Emerging Research National (ERN) Conference in STEM for EFRI and ERC REM awardees and through hosting EFRI and ERC REM Research Mentor Training Seminars. We also established a website for the EFRI-REM Mentoring Catalyst initiative. Additional products arising from this initiative included several conference presentations, a book, a dissertation, and a new course developed to introduce 1st year undergraduate engineering students to research and mentoring. Through this initiative, we trained over 300 graduate students and post-doctoral fellows, and 60 faculty and staff from 17 different institutions.
